questions.question: 1. Which of these best describes an array?

answers.a: A data structure that shows a hierarchical behaviour
answers.b: Container of objects of similar types
answers.c: Container of objects of mixed types

explanations.a: The data structure that shows hierarchical behaviour is a tree, and hence it is the wrong answer.
explanations.b: As we have read earlier a simple container for objects of similar types is an array, they might be integer, characters or any custom class objects, Hence this is the correct description for an array.
explanations.c: We have a 'list' that is similar to an array but is a container of objects of mixed types, and hence is not an array and is the wrong answer.
explanations.d: Only one of the mentioned answers describes an array and hence it cannot be all.

questions.question: 2. What is the time complexity of insertion at any point in an array?
3. Pick incorrect options from the following

answers.a: If structure contains 3 types of data then one pointer is sufficient for that structure
answers.b: One variable can be bound to many structures
answers.c: Contents of a structure are stored in contiguous memory

explanations.a: A structure itself acts as a custom data type consisting of the 3 types of data and hence, a single pointer is sufficient to point to the structure.
explanations.b: One variable cannot be bound to multiple structures.
explanations.c: Contents of the structure are stored continuously in the memory, hence this statement is correct

questions.question: 4. The memory occupied by a pointer _______

answers.a: Is independent on which data type the pointer points to.
answers.c: Depends on the program we are writing,

explanations.a: A pointer pointing to any data type ultimately is just a variable that stores a memory address. The space required to store memory address is independent of what the memory address holds. Hence this is incorrect.
explanations.b: As memory address is always a hexadecimal, it will depend on the system you are using. It will occupy 4 bytes on 32 bit system and 8 bytes on a 64 bit system. But is completely independent on which data type it is storing.
explanations.c: Incorrect. It depends, only on which system we are declaring the pointer.
